pros: Caring work environment Amazing team

job_title: Social Worker/Case Manager in East St Johnsbry, VT
pros: good to get a foot in the door in social services
cons: case loads were large minimal supervisory support

review_title: Some nice people, but ultimately large changes are needed
pros:
Some staff enjoyable to work with 
Flexible with time off/working from home (for admin staff)
Lots of CEUs
Benefits decent if you are single
cons:
Executive staff talk far too much about money, seem extremely disconnected from front line staff. 

Burnout is seen as an individual problem rather than systemic.

DEI conversations handled in a tone-deaf manner. 

Cost to add a dependent to health insurance is laughable.

Exec staff will gaslight you into thinking they are making horrible decisions for your benefit.

Toxic work culture that involves decisions made by executive staff behind closed doors, no shared decision making and lashing out if decisions are questioned. Even sometimes senior program directors are left out of the loop.

Staff who have been there for years leaving in droves.

pros: Clients need services, and are great.
cons: Management only cares about productivity and will not help you if you're struggling.

pros: Dedicated clinicians who care about the clients. The extended Illness bank for leave is a great process. Overall benefits were good, albeit very expensive to add a dependent.
cons: Where to start? Burnt out upper management that wasn’t listening and didn’t want to put in the work. If you were younger and a part of that team, they took advantage of you, gaslit you, and burned you out until you didn’t know who you were anymore. Exec team is completely misaligned with the mission, values, and needs of their staff. The result? People leave with so much anger and trauma they need to go into other fields or private practice to escape so it not only harms LW but harms the whole industry.

job_title: Office Support Specialist II in Portland, OR
pros: Great working environments and training. Focused on Diversity and inclusion.
cons: Does need to improve on pay.

job_title: Peer Support Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Typing five words as required.
cons:
One of many churches of Woke/social justice/critical feminist nonsense in the Portland area.

If you value sanity, don't work here. Avoid as if it were Covid.

I spent a tad over 6 years (too long) working for a program serving teens and young adults. The first year or so was OK but things went downhill after that as more and more politics/ideology was introduced. Trainings, articles/books, posters, speakers, statements by upper management.. all saturated in the kind of propaganda that is now so seemingly commonplace in society. Very unfortunate.

What I learned is that the job was much less about providing meaningful support to clients than it was about virtue signaling. And the kinds of people you can expect to work with, at least in my experience, are either naïve (at best) or Nurse Ratched types.

I strongly suspect that one of my former supervisors was associated with Antifa.

Here are a few interesting statements made by either my supervisor or select members of my team over the years (no disciplinary action taken):

"I hate men."
"White people are the devil."
"We're all socialists here."
"Individualism is white supremacy."
"Capitalism is patriarchy."

And so on. Super professional stuff here. Great idea to bring to the workplace.

Lots of gaslighting, guilt tripping too.

All of this gleefully camouflaged by glitter, rainbows, and unicorns. Such love, such inclusion, such respect. A unicorn rubber ducky was used to award staff in my program for going 'above and beyond'. No, I'm not making this up.

The organization, as a whole, made it a point to signal their virtue over current events on a regular to placate employees and likely to maintain/secure sources of funding. They were big on bandwagoning the BLM movement at the time, probably still are even now that they've been outed as a criminal enterprise.

Don't bother bringing any of this to the attention of HR. They are staffed by SJWs. They love careers in administration. At best, you will be ignored. At worst, you will be placed on a plan with intent to terminate.

So.. again.. if you consider yourself a thinking person and aren't on-board with the woke garbage in this day and age, avoid the hassle and apply elsewhere. Unfortunately most of the nonprofits like this are about the same now (corrupt) so your options are going to be limited.

Good luck.

review_title: Overall a wonderful company with great values
pros:
First I will start with transparency. LifeWorksNW's transparency has grown exponentially over the past 5 years. The executive team is deeply involved and offers support and a listening ear to anyone seeking, which in my past experience was never the case. LifeworksNW employees 700+ people ranging in all different fields of service so you could imagine the hard work it takes to lead a company of that magnitude. I have never experienced an executive team being so involved in the team environment before, and yes it poses some challenges at times but I think it speaks volumes to this company and how it is being ran. Just last week the executive VP of Operations offered to sit at the front desk to answer phones because we were short staffed. This alone shows how humble and supportive they are. 

Second the compensation, benefits and time off are top notch for this industry. 

Lastly, the team comradery is very strong at Lifeworksnw. I feel a strong sense of "I got your back" in pretty much every aspect of my job. THAT is what keeps me at this job. I love my peers and my staff. When it seems like everything is on fire and its absolute chaos, Im always reassured knowing I have a strong team and fellow peers that are there along side me the whole way. Managers are also provided an appreciation fund each quarter to take their employees out to lunch or buy them coffee from time to time just to build moral and feel appreciated.
cons:
Coaching up or coaching out is a struggle. Emphasis on the coaching out to be completely honest. Because Lifeworks is such a wonderful company to work, there are managers/staff that have been here for a long time that no longer embody the values that LifeworksNW, they struggle to lead change, an/or do not hold their teams accountable. 

Another con would be embracing change. Change does not come easy to LifeworksNW but I have seen some improvements.

review_title: low salary, high expectations and executive staff that are inexcusably detached from the reality of frontline work
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Portland, OR
pros:
-benefits are OK
-PTO is good after 2 years
-great coworkers and clients
cons:
-executive leadership that do not communicate with lower management or frontline staff in any meaningful capacity.
-executive staff that make policy changes behind closed doors that directly impact staff without an input and announcing these changes via email.
-low pay and no room for negotiation.
-executive staff often don't present data or reasoning behind decisions
-executive staff choose white men to host and facilitate majority of trainings
-staff are treated as expendable
-tone deaf emails from executive staff after culturally traumatic events that  don't include ways to help or any meaning action the agency will take to serve impacted staff or clients
-executive staff think the word 'equity' means 'equality'

job_title: Early Childhood Educator in Chesterfield, MO
pros:
I loved working with my close group of co teachers at the Lifeworks NW St Johns nursery.

We had full benefits and competitive pay.
cons: Working long hours with little to no flexibility for time off

review_title: I believe in this company and their mission!
job_title: Certified Alcohol and Drug Counselor II in Portland, OR
pros: Solid dedicated company in the Portland Meto area. Great team of people and staff who really care to help!
cons: Company has difficulty retaining staff long term and that leaves the staff that stays to carry the weight.

pros:
Remote work
Design your own schedule

Management
Time off
Feeling supported 
Reimbursement for travel needs to be adjusted

review_title: Love this company, it's dedication to the communities it serves and the people doing the work that really care!
pros: A company that is always looking at ways to improve connection with diversity and inclusion of all that are in need.
cons: Pandemic has led to distance from clients.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: The front desk staff are nice
cons:
Caseloads are outrageous
Level of care assessments don't line up with how often clients are seen
Emails about performance and documentation from Supervisors are ridiculous, considering the only way to doc your sessions is after hours, because your entire 8 hour day is back to back clients
Supervisors are also leaving in droves, meaning you may not be receiving supervision at all, even where required by licensure and the state

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: The clients, working with committed co-workers
cons: Upper management seriously needs to retire- fresh ideas and leadership needed. Pay is low for the work we do.

review_title: Higher Pay than other places, not the best care of clients and staff
pros: pay is higher than other places for the kind of work done
cons: Unresponsive HR department, poorly trained clinicians, the way they run their facilities does not match their mission statement overall.

review_title: The work is rewarding but the management is terrible
pros: Rewarding work and the clients are great. There are great little deals from time to time like getting 50% at Columbia.
cons: The upper management that oversees the management at each location is awful. They are out of touch of what is really going on In the everyday stuff. Unrealistic goals that are set for staff to achieve more like a cattle call

review_title: They will not consider your experience in salary offers or increases.
job_title: Dual Doagnosis Therapist in Portland, OR
pros: Great overall experience for an intern.
cons: Consideration of actual experience toward initial salary or salary increases. They will NOT give you a fair or equal salary. They even ask for volunteers to work as a supervisor if you are qualified but will not offer a supervisors salary for your services. Sadly, the supervisor making the request said they would tell management I was just :not available", that was not true. I suggested they tell them I said no due to the salary...crickets.

pros:
Flexibility is wonderful 
Dedicated leaders
Mission driven
cons: Exec team is all legacy. Would love to see fresh, new faces and ideas.

pros:
Every program operates differently, this feedback is specifically for the school based care coordination position:
-Flexible schedule 
-Supportive team
-Documentation requirements not too complex
cons:
-No room for growth
-Not too clinical
-Can get redundant at times

job_title: Dual Diagnosis Therapist in Hillsboro, OR
pros: Lifeworks NW is a wonderful place to work and often times I have full range of how my counseling looks as well as the support I need to grow as a counselor.
cons: The main downside is that as a non-profit the potential for growth is limited. Additionally some of the policies from the upper administration is detached from the work being done on the ground.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Portland, OR
pros: People who work here genuinely care about clients
cons: Management is bloated, often has unrealistic expectations about what can reasonably be done in a 40 hour work week

pros: Good pay and liked boss a lot
cons: hard to move up but could if tried

pros: Open dialogue, good work life balance, not micro managed.
cons: Too brief training period, lack of upward mobility.

review_title: Overall good company to work for
pros: Mission focused, flexible work environment.
cons: Tough job with limited resources. If you're lucky to have a supportive and connected manager you will do fine

pros: The people in my program were awesome. I miss working wih them. They were passionate about what they do. Plus, my supervisors were very easy going and I looked forward to seeing them at weekly meetings.
cons: I worked as a front desk floater for several months. I went to several offices and no one who worked in administration work would interact with me. On top of that, the clinicians treated me pretty horribly. One I moved to a clinical roll, admin people were kind to me. I worked in a community based program, which can be pretty dangerous, and was paid pennies. The higher ups care more about numbers than the people who work for them or the clients. While I was there I was not able to put my kids on medical because it would be about a third of my monthly income. For an organization that says "life works when you get the support you need" they don't seem to care about supporting their people.

pros: The people, the mission of the organization, the benefits package for employees.  The agency really invested in training me well upon hire.  There is a very professional yet friendly attitude coming down from just about every level of management, and my supervisors are excellent.  I get to work with people in my community who are in need in a unique way.  The culture and values of this agency are probably the best practiced (and not just said in your orientation) of any company I've worked for before.
cons: I love absolutely every aspect of this job except... trying to make ends meet as a single individual on this salary.  I am a master's level clinician and I am being paid VERY poorly compared to other jobs in the field and even in this region.

job_title: Adolescent Milieu Counselor in Tigard, OR
pros: I work with a great crew and we have a very relaxed office culture with great interpersonal relationships. The work itself is rewarding, as we get to help troubled teens improve their lives. Probably the best-paying non-profit in the Portland area.
cons: Unfortunately, probably the best-paying non-profit in the Portland area. We have been understaffed for the past 5 months, and we are all scrambling to provide adequate coverage for our clients, which frequently leads to them falling through the cracks. Raises are unheard of, and our program manager has gone 4 months without seeing a financial report (that streak may still be going, we don't know). Morale is low, and we're constantly being told to do more because we're admitting everyone we can, including clients that belong in a much higher level of treatment, even though we're still understaffed. We're all getting burned out with no real compensation for our efforts or support from upper management. PTO policy is backward and frustrating.

job_title: Supported Housing Specialist in Beaverton, OR
pros: I worked for a really great manager in a grant funded program and I was really happy for the great experience that I got there. They also provided frequent training and free licensure supervision.
cons: Many other programs including ones the I interacted with did not have such great managers and I heard some real horror stories. They also worked for programs that were not grant funded and had very high billing requirements to meet their productivity requirements and were often mistreated  by management if they did not make them. Interestingly enough the productivity in my program with no official productivity standard was nearly identical to theirs and of course everyone was just below the cut-off. (Meaning that pressuring people to do more had absolutely no affect on their productivity.

pros: LifeWorks has plenty of incredible programs available for the marginalized populations in our area. The people who work here are typically incredible individuals who care about contributing to their community and helping people change their lives for the better. There have also been plenty of training opportunities available.
cons: It seems that once a person gets a job here it is almost impossible for them to get fired. Even if there is overwhelming reason and plenty of documented evidence to justify firing an individual, it rarely happens. You can show up to work drunk in a cab paid for by the company and still only be placed on an "action plan". I'm all for supporting the workers but not when it's at the cost of the work environment. Inept, inexperienced, and easily overwhelmed people populate full-time positions while those with experience, dedication, and passion for their work are lost as they find jobs elsewhere.

review_title: Great Company, I was sad to leave
job_title: Qualified Mental Health Associate in Forest Grove, OR
pros:
I loved my co-workers and supervisor here. Everyone was very supportive and encouraged questions. I learned a lot about behavioral interventions here and I think it will help me in my future career.  This company has a great orientation training which really sets their employees up for success. During the training, we spoke about ways to have a good work-life balance. 
I usually worked weekends, but my supervisor made efforts to be available to me by giving me her personal and work phone numbers. This made it easy for me to check in with her about the clients and ask her what behavioral intervention she would recommend.
cons: The only downside to working at LifeWorks was the lack of personal over the weekends, which is when I usually worked. There were other health care professionals around but it would have been nice if another mental health associate was there.

pros: That I did not start screaming  and never stop,
cons: That I actually stayed  there for three  whole days before resigning.

pros: Supportive co-workers, better pay than most, good health benefits for a single person, helpful learning experience for assessment, differential diagnosis, and counseling skills.
cons: Lack of clarification about job duties! INSANE productivity and paperwork expectations. Mixed messages constantly. Somehow asking us to do more work for clients yet spend less time billing for them. Caseloads that average 70 clients per counselor. Expected to only spend 60-90 minutes per month on each client, even though people deserve so much more help. OH and billing/ productivity is the only thing managers discuss with you. Minimal time spent on clinical supervision. These factors may be true for many community mental health agencies, and if so, it demonstrates that this is a truly broken system. I do think that support from a supervisor can minimize or maximize these inherent problems, though.

pros: The reason I stayed at Lifeworks for so long was the amazing group of people (clinicians and admin staff alike) that I got to work with. I always felt supported by my immediate supervisors, but never by upper management.
cons: he pay for clinicians is very low, especially considering the population you work with. The clinical work was intensely stressful at times and it sucked to feel like no one really cared about what you were doing. The organization itself has a lot of issues that were never worked on during the 6 years I was an employee.

job_title: Office Support CCBHC in Portland, OR
pros: Better pay than similar agencies, at least for now while they have the grant. Flexible start times and leave times, but not with days.
cons: Unprofessional management, no training for office managers of how to interact with people with mental illness, nepotism, favoritism, negative culture and work environment,  tense and dishonest  environment, over populated with floats, undependable hours some weeks you get no hours, expect unbennefitted employees to be as available as full time employees, not flexible with our for students or people with any outside committments and are punished for it.

review_title: Recent psychology, social work and counseling grads...look elsewhere.
pros: Great peers. Clinicians care about what they are doing.
cons: Low morale, exploitation of employees ranging from clinical front desk staff to prescribers, poor pay, sub-par PTO policy

pros: flexible, supportive work environment. Managers are approachable, and have done the work of the line staff in the past, so understand the challenges. Regular pay increases. Encourage and allow regular attendance at trainings and conferences.
cons: Clinicians have high caseloads and high productivity requirements, that are difficult to meet. Pay is reasonable, but not great, because it is a non-profit agency.

review_title: Chaotic, lots of clients, heavy paperwork demands
pros: helping people who need it
cons: low pay,  bad benefits for families, excessive paperwork, infrequent supervision, lots of employee turnover, low morale.  Not only do they hire people with diploma mill PhDs to be a supervisor, they terminate or lay you off over the telephone!  Their middle managers and program managers make almost double what the front line clinicians make.

review_title: Could be worse...but it should be a whole lot better
pros: Supportive clinical supervisors;best coworkers
cons: Grossly incompetent Senior management; Extremely top heavy; A culture of disrespect, abuse that devalues and demeans CD Clinicians and by proxy SUD clients in their care;  where poor management decisions and revenue shortfalls are simply solved by increasing the amount of money and clients CD Clinicians are required to bring in every month

review_title: Knowledgeable, caring line staff doing their best despite confusing direction from middle management.
pros: Qualified co-workers deliver direct care and ready to work with you, flexible hours & time off, culture supports diversity; nice benefits make up for lower wages
cons: new electronic medical record, lower payscale

review_title: Senior management totally disconnected from line staff
pros: Good PTO and benefits, opportunities to help clients, good coworkers.
cons: Beyond terrible communication accompanying lots of changes to systems and processes. The top managers at my site seem to hate their jobs and are frequently absent. They just keep hiring more highly paid non clinical directors, who make clinical decisions.

review_title: I Worked in offices for nineteen years
pros: I am someone who keeps a busy schedule and enjoys getting a lot done, I consider myself to be someone who is creative and enjoys developing new approach's to solve problems.
cons: I am careful not away push for the new way

job_title: Service Coordinator I in Milwaukie, OR
pros: Supportive Teams, Company works to increase salaries and was looking at housing for employees
cons: Pay is too low on a single income with student loans to compensate for the cost of living in the Portland area. No room for advancement at the Bachelors level, training could be improved to reduce wasted time. Training is done by other employees. Managers could be more involved in training

pros: PTO . Employees who truly care about the client’s success
cons: The communication between departments and programs is fractured. The clients see the disorganization and feel frustrated .It’s  not trauma informed to have inconsistency. There are definite favorite employees who can do no wrong and have little respect for how their behavior affects their coworkers and the clients

pros: Insurance, PTO. Peers, administration staff
cons: Lack of paid holidays without reducing PTO. Unfair pay practices. Supervisors not held accountable for high turn over. Impossible to meet documentation standards without working significant OT and then balked at for wanting to flex time.

review_title: The worst! Not really...but kind of.
pros: Admin staff are highly compensated. Way more than clinical staff!And the further up the chain of command you'll find high levels of incompetence. Which makes for hilarious commentary for your loved one's when they ask about your day at work.
cons:
It's all about the bottom line...$$$.
The clinical staff are so overworked It's disgraceful. Too many admin staff, getting paid too much (most of them barely literate...not a joke). Nepotism. Borderline state and county funding fraud. Mass misuse of funds that could go to client care.

pros: Dedicated staff - management, support and direct service; mission-focused agency
cons: Salaries do not recognize the value of the workforce which is typical of behavioral health provider organizations due to lack of adequate funding.

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Tigard, OR

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Tigard, OR
pros: great team work, everyone is young in the counselor role
cons: It is not by the book whatsoever. Too much afterwork mingling that changed the dynamic of good work.
